resources.string: "Bluetooth not enabled, please visit device settings and enable bluetooth to be able to receive measurements from your connected devices"
Permissions not granted, please visit device settings and grant required bluetooth permissions be able to receive measurements from your connected devices"
Paired devices will appear here once set up. Press (+) button to pair a new device.
Are you sure you want to permanently remove this health record? This action cannot be undone.
Unable to delete the health record. Please try again.
Heart rate is the number of times your heart beats per minute. Checking your heart rate helps your care team see how you are responding to your meds and if any meds need to be changed.
"Everyoneâ€™s normal heart rate is different. A heart rate under 50 can make you dizzy. If your heart rate suddenly increases and stays high, you should tell your care team. "
Your heart rate will be checked when you take your blood pressure. For more info, see the heart rate video.
When the heart is weak, your body can hold onto more salt and water and your weight can rise quickly. This can lead to trouble breathing, leg swelling, and stomach bloating.
Small changes in weight are normal. But if you gain over 3 pounds in a day or over 5 pounds in a week, talk to your care team.
Check your weight every day at the same time of day to see if there may be fluid buildup. For more info, see the weight video.
Blood pressure measures the force in your blood vessels as your heart pumps blood in your body. Check your blood pressure daily to track your heart and how it is responding to your meds.

The top number of the blood pressure (called systolic) should be under 130 mmHg. The blood pressure that is too low is different for each person and should be discussed with your care team. If your blood pressure is too low, it can make you feel dizzy.
Do not exercise in the 30 minutes before taking your blood pressure. Make sure the cuff fits well around your upper arm, and keep your legs uncrossed. For more info, see the blood pressure video.
Hold down the bluetooth button for 3 seconds to put the device into pairing mode.
Do you want to pair %1$s with ENGAGEHF app?
%1$s was successfully paired with ENGAGEHF app
Something went wrong, please try again later.
On target dose that best helps your heart
On medication but may benefit from a higher dose
Not on this medication that may help your heart

This score shows how your heart failure affects you overall. You can score 0 to 100. A higher score means you are doing better. Over 80 is often considered doing well. A goal of heart medicines is to improve this score over time or keep it from decreasing.
This represents how your heart affects your ability to do activity. Higher scores mean you are less limited, and over 80 is often considered doing well.
This score represents how your heart affects your ability to do social activities. Higher scores mean you are able to do more, while lower scores mean you are more limited by your heart.
This score represents how content you are with your heart symptoms. Higher scores mean you are overall more content, while lower scores mean you are less satisfied with how you are doing.
This represents the frequency you are experiencing heart-related symptoms. Higher scores mean less frequent symptoms and lower scores mean more frequent symptoms.
Your dizziness is important to keep track of because dizziness can be a side effect of your heart or your heart medicines.
Health Summary generated successfully, but no PDF reader is installed on the device"
